pr_title: [GEOS-9663] Add support for GEOJSON output in the JSON-LD module and rename it

timeline.author: aaime

timeline.bodyText: Wondering why the GeoJson writer has a writeValue method that looks a lot smarter than the jsonld one?
timeline.author: aaime

replies.bodyText: Because Json-ld needs every value encoded as a string
replies.author: taba90

timeline.bodyText: Looking at the code, it seems the flat output is managed also in JSON_LD mode. I would clarify that's the case, renaming this section "Flat output mode" and then making an example that cites the new  INSPIRE flat GeoJSON as an example.
timeline.author: aaime

+Inspire GeoJSON Output
+----------------------
+
+In order to provide a GeoJSON output encoded following INSPIRE rule for `alternative feature GeoJSON encoding <https://github.com/INSPIRE-MIF/2017.2/blob/master/GeoJSON/ads/simple-addresses.md>`_, it is possible to provide a VendorOption in the template file by adding the following attribute :code:`"$VendorOptions": "flat_output:true"`.

replies.bodyText: Indeed it looked like that, but it was a leftover, since json-ld was not supposed to support the flat_output param, I've cleaned up the code. An example for the GeoJSON INSPIRE output has been included in the output section of documentation 7e555b4#diff-32de36cbd8049c697cfbeba5baf98c9bR247
replies.author: taba90

timeline.bodyText: Confused... here it checks only the first feature type, but then during the loop each feature type is checked for template presence too. So, isn't this check redundant? The same seems to be happening in the GEoJSONTemplateGetFeatureResponse
timeline.author: aaime

replies.bodyText:
Indeed that is a dummy check.
The reason for that is that json-ld output is working for one featureType only. To make it able to encode more then one layer a strategy to handle multiple context is needed. Since GeoJSON doesn't have context I made json-ld response encoding multiple layer too, with a temporary workaround using only the context available from the first featureType.
But was a bad idea, since was not a really solution. I've restored the previous behaviour.
replies.author: taba90

timeline.bodyText:
This class and GeoJsonTemplateGetFeatureResponse look very similar to me... comparing them with a diff tool, seem to suggest they might be actually the same class, with parameters to specify which type of builders to use,

timeline.bodyText: Unsure what's happening here... seems like a workaround for an issue with response resolution? Ah, I'm guessing the dispatcher would not be happy to see two responses producing the same output for the same request and mime type, and it would conflict with the main GeoJSON response?

replies.author: taba90

timeline.bodyText: Could you please reduce a bit the nesting level? There is no requirement to put everything in the same method, once you determined you want to replace the response, you can call a different method that does exactly that, and give it a name that explains the purpose in the process too (e.g., "replaceResponse(...)").
timeline.author: aaime

timeline.bodyText: When the formatter starts wrapping variable declaration and simple assignments over two lines, it's a sign you're nesting too much, try to split the method in two or more, keep shorter (but significant, and well named) methods instead.
